replies.msg:
歐洲食品安全局表示，傳統的醃製和冷熏皆不 足以殺死魚內的寄生蟲;在特定條件下進行冷凍和 加熱才是殺死魚內寄生蟲最有效的方法。根據食品 法典委員會的《魚和漁業製品操作規範》，一般情況 下，把供生吃的魚類在-20°C或以下冷凍七天;或 在-35°C冷凍約20小時，便能殺死魚內的寄生蟲

https://www.cfs.gov.hk/english/multimedia/multimedia_pub/files/FSF123_2016_10_19.pdf

replies.msg:
The freezing clearly killed bacteria, and keeping it frozen for longer killed more bacteria. But freezing did not kill ALL bacteria. The re-freezing method was more successful.

In 1938, scientists did a similar study to see what happens if you freeze bacteria at different temperatures for different lengths of time (The Effect of Freezing on Bacteria). Here’s are the number of survivors over 150 days:





They found that freezing killed bacteria, but again not 100%. The longer they were frozen, the more bacteria died.

Conclusion: Freezing kills bacteria, but not all bacteria (at least not right away). Freezing for longer amounts of time kills more bacteria, as does repeated freezing and thawing.

Reference:
Haines R B. (1938). The Effects of Freezing on Bacteria.

replies.msg:
個post 算唔算俾樓主自己騎劫咗？

Btw 喺可以嘅，大多數細菌都無cell wall, 凍到零度細胞嘅水份理論上就會結冰，一解凍就會死，因為水分子起固態佔據多啲空間，起冰格將水雪成冰會脹起少少。

但喺唔會殺得晒所有菌，因為有啲菌種喺可以抵禦極低温，所以多數情況下喺唔能夠完全滅絕啲菌。

https://www.quora.com/Does-freezing-kill-bacteria-How-cold-does-it-have-to-be

The freezing clearly killed bacteria, and keeping it frozen for longer killed more bacteria. But freezing did not kill ALL bacteria. The re-freezing method was more successful.

In 1938, scientists did a similar study to see what happens if you freeze bacteria at different temperatures for different lengths of time (The Effect of Freezing on Bacteria). Here’s are the number of survivors over 150 days:





They found that freezing killed bacteria, but again not 100%. The longer they were frozen, the more bacteria died.

Conclusion: Freezing kills bacteria, but not all bacteria (at least not right away). Freezing for longer amounts of time kills more bacteria, as does repeated freezing and thawing.

Reference:
Haines R B. (1938). The Effects of Freezing on Bacteria.

replies.msg:
我有無睇錯
原來高溫啲殺菌勁啲

The effectiveness of freezing to kill parasites depends on several factors, including the temperature of the freezing process, the length of time needed to freeze the fish tissue, the length of time the fish is held frozen, the species and source of the fish, and the type of parasite present. The temperature of the freezing process, the length
of time the fish is held frozen, and the type of parasite appear to be the most important factors. For example, tapeworms are more susceptible to freezing than are roundworms. Flukes appear to be more resistant to freezing than roundworms.

Freezing and storing at an ambient temperature
of -4°F (-20°C) or below for 7 days (total time),
or freezing at an ambient temperature of -31°F (-35°C) or below until solid and storing at an ambient temperature of -31°F (-35°C) or below for 15 hours, or freezing at an ambient temperature of -31°F (-35°C) or below until solid and storing at an ambient temperature of -4°F (-20°C) or below for 24 hours are sufficient to kill parasites. Note that these conditions may not be suitable for freezing particularly large fish (e.g., thicker than 6 inches).

source: https://www.fda.gov/downloads/food/guidanceregulation/ucm252393.pdf
